plants.name: Rhododendron simsii
plants.description: Azaleas are flowering shrubs known for their vibrant clusters of funnel-shaped flowers and evergreen foliage. They thrive in acidic soils and are popular in temperate gardens worldwide.
plants.location: Temperate regions of Eastern Asia and cultivated globally
plants.funFact: Azaleas were originally wild plants native to Asia, but many hybrids have been developed for gardens all over the world.

plants.name: Lupinus perennis
plants.description: A North American native wildflower characterized by tall spikes of pea-like flowers and palmate leaves. It plays a crucial role in local ecosystems as a nitrogen fixer and host for butterfly larvae.
plants.location: Eastern United States and Canada, in sandy or well-drained soils
plants.funFact: Wild Lupine is the primary host plant for the endangered Karner blue butterfly.

plants.name: Nerium oleander
plants.description: An evergreen shrub commonly found in Mediterranean climates, known for its fragrant, showy flowers and drought tolerance. Despite its beauty, it is toxic if ingested.
plants.location: Mediterranean Basin, South Asia, cultivated worldwide in warm climates
plants.funFact: Oleander extracts were historically used medicinally, but all parts of the plant are toxic due to cardiac glycosides.

plants.name: Jacaranda mimosifolia
plants.description: A tropical/subtropical tree celebrated for its extravagant display of trumpet-shaped violet-blue flowers and fern-like leaves. It is widely planted in cities for shade and ornamental value.
plants.location: Native to South America, cultivated in subtropical regions worldwide (e.g., Australia, South Africa)
